docs.lead_paragraph: While the election in three weeks has been portrayed in Washington as a referendum on whether President Clinton should be impeached, the Lewinsky scandal has not been a central part of the discourse -- or the candidates' strategies -- in the closest House and Senate contests in the country. In recent days, polls showing a backlash against the Republican Congress have led many Republicans to stop touting the Clinton scandal as a plus for their campaigns. No Republican House candidate is currently running a commercial that mentions the matter, according to party officials; only weeks ago, a handful did.

headline.main: Monica Who? Say Candidates In Close Races

docs.snippet: While the election in three weeks has been portrayed in Washington as a referendum on whether President Clinton should be impeached, the Lewinsky scandal has not been a central part of the discourse -- or the candidates' strategies -- in the closest...

docs.lead_paragraph: United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, who throughout her campaign for Connecticut governor has touched on many issues but never found a theme, tonight unified her concerns about the state's future by asserting that the prosperity trumpeted by Gov. John G. Rowland amounts to only half of ''a tale of two states.'' Mrs. Kennelly, a Democrat, used the second of four debates to present what amounted to a closing argument for her candidacy, and her staff said she planned to stick to the theme every day through the election on Nov. 3.

headline.main: Kennelly, in Debate, Sees Two States, One Struggling

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration is asking a full appeals court to overturn an August ruling that gave new rights and consumer protections to six million Medicare beneficiaries in health maintenance organizations. Advocates for the elderly had hailed the earlier ruling, by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, as an important victory. The panel said that decisions by Medicare H.M.O.'s amounted to Government actions, so that patients denied specific services were entitled to ''due process of law,'' including hearings and other protections.

headline.main: White House Seeks to Block Care Ruling

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration asks full appeals court to overturn ruling that gives new rights and consumer protections to six million Medicare beneficiaries in health maintenance organizations; says Government should not be held accountable for actions of HMO's that sign contracts with Medicare; lower court ruled decisions by Medicare HMO's amounted to Government actions, so that patients denied specific services are entitled to due process, including hearings and new protections (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Humana Inc. and Foundation Health Systems Inc. said last week that they would get a second chance to bid on a $2 billion Defense Department contract that they lost to Anthem Insurance Companies Inc. last year. Humana, a Louisville, Ky., health insurer, said the Defense Department had agreed to reopen bidding on the contract to provide health care services for more than one million people after the company protested that parts of the original bidding process had been unfair. Foundation, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., also complained.

headline.main: Insurers Get 2d Bid On U.S. Contract

docs.abstract: Humana Inc and Foundation Health Systems Inc say they will get second chance to bid on $2 billion Defense Department contract that they lost to Anthem Insurance Companies Inc last year; Humana says department has agreed to reopen bidding to provide health care services for more than one million people after company protested that parts of original bidding process had been unfair (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE annual conferences and meetings of the advertising industry trade associations are almost always like Kabuki or No theater -- highly stylized, ritualized events carefully choreographed on the theory that, to quote the old ad slogan, the best surprise is no surprise. So it was startling when officials at the 89th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, held here at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, sharply deviated from the familiar patterns with unexpected news: They would for the first time open their membership to regional and national agencies that create all types of advertising.

headline.main: National Association of Advertisers startles agencies by offering to admit them as members.

docs.abstract: Association of National Advertisers, meeting, Naples, Fla, offers to open membership to regional and national advertising agencies that create all types of ads; president John J Sarsen Jr cites agencies' key role in building brand equity; American Association of Advertising Agencies president O Burtch Drake, who attends meeting, lauds proposal, but is dismayed at not being informed earlier (M)
docs.snippet: THE annual conferences and meetings of the advertising industry trade associations are almost always like Kabuki or No theater -- highly stylized, ritualized events carefully choreographed on the theory that, to quote the old ad slogan, the best...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: An Oct. 8 editorial on California's Proposition 10 does not mention that a similar effort is under way in New York. The Kids' Health Initiative, sponsored by groups like the American Cancer Society, American Heart Association, American Lung Association and Medical Society of the State of New York, seeks to raise the price of cigarettes $1 a pack.

headline.main: Cigarette Tax Only Sounds Like a Good Idea; New York's Effort

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani publicly questioned Gov. George E. Pataki's decision to accept the endorsement of the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d yesterday, saying the prominent black minister ''plays the worst kind of race politics.'' It was not surprising to hear Mr. Giuliani denounce Mr. Butts, the pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, who infuriated the Mayor last spring by calling him a racist who was on the verge of creating a fascist state. But it was highly unusual for Mr. Giuliani to question publicly the judgment of Mr. Pataki, who is seeking re-election this fall and is a fellow Republican.

headline.main: Mayor Faults Pataki Approval Of Harlem Minister's Support

docs.abstract: New York City Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani publicly questions Gov George E Pataki's decision to accept endorsement of Rev Calvin O Butts 3d, saying the prominent black minister 'plays the worst kind of racial politics'; photo of Pataki and Butts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: At the end of the year New York City will implement a plan requiring Medicaid recipients to enroll in managed care plans (front page, Oct. 7). Approximately one-fifth of the city's nonelderly population is on Medicaid.

headline.main: Managed Care Plans Shirk Their Duty

docs.abstract: Dave Silver letter questions who will monitor quality of health care for the poor after New York City implements plan requiring Medicaid recipients to enroll in managed care plans

docs.lead_paragraph: Stephane Barthe is one of the many fine French riders who will not be competing today in the world championship bicycle road race in Valkenburg, the Netherlands. While most of the others are ineligible because they have been accused of doping, Barthe is staying away in protest. ''I do not want to represent France after what happened in the Tour de France,'' Barthe, the 25-year-old former national champion, said last week.

headline.main: Riders Are Still Critical of the French Police and Courts for Their Role in Drug Affair

docs.abstract: Stephane Barthe is one of many French bicycle riders who will not be competing in world championship bicycle road race in Valkenburg, the Netherlands; while most of the others are ineligible because they have been accused of doping, Barthe is staying away in protest; Barthe is critical of French police and courts in their role in drug affair at Tour de France two months ago (M)
